questions.question_text: Outline your organization's cyber incident reporting process under DFARS 252.204-7012.
questions.suggested_answer:
{ "answers": [ { "id": "incident_reporting_process", "answer": "

Cyber Incident Reporting Process

We have a well-documented process for reporting and responding to cyber incidents, aligned with DFARS 252.204-7012 requirements.

Step 1: Detection and Identification
  • Incident detection is performed by our Security Information and Event Management (SIEM) system.
  • The incident is identified and escalated to the Incident Response Team (IRT).
Step 2: Initial Assessment and Containment
  • The IRT performs an initial assessment of the incident, including identifying affected systems and data.
  • The IRT contains the incident by disconnecting affected systems from the network and applying patches or workarounds as necessary.
Step 3: Incident Reporting and Notification
  • The IRT reports the incident to our management, including a preliminary assessment of impact and scope.
  • We notify the relevant stakeholders, including customers and contracting officers, in accordance with DFARS 252.204-7012 requirements.
Step 4: Incident Response and Recovery
  • The IRT develops and implements an incident response plan, including measures to prevent recurrence and recover affected systems.
  • We review and update our incident response procedures as necessary, incorporating lessons learned from the incident.

questions.question_text: Describe your Zero Trust architecture components and enforcement mechanisms.
questions.suggested_answer: Our Zero Trust architecture is based on a defense-in-depth approach that integrates multiple security controls to enforce least privilege access and segmentation across all environments. Key components include multi-factor authentication (MFA), network access control lists (ACLs), and micro-segmentation with software-defined networking (SDN). Enforcement mechanisms are designed to continuously monitor and adapt to changing network conditions, ensuring that only authorized users and systems have access to CUI. The organization's SSP provides detailed documentation of these controls and procedures, which are regularly reviewed and updated to ensure alignment with NIST SP 800-171 and DFARS 252.204-7012 requirements.
